results.title: H-16 camera with wood and aluminum tripod
results.brief_description:
Paillard Bolex H-16 Movie Camera for 16mm 100’ Rolls Complete with 3 Lenses, instruction book, Bolex 1948 catalog, Wollensak Cine Lenses catalog and Kodak Cine Ektar Lenses catalog, special fitted leather case, two finders H 16-F 150 and H 16-F 25. The lenses are an Elgeet 13mm f1.5 Wide Angle, Cooke Telekinic Anastigmat 3 inch f4, and Wollensak 1 inch f1.5 Cine Raptar.
Also a roll of 16mm Kodachrome film dated November 1953.
[Tripod - see AEO179215]

results.title: Home country
results.creator_credit: Julie Mongta-Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Julie Mongta/Saunders traces the movement of her family over time, both geographically and generationally. Though scattered, this family have a strong connection, both to each other and the land of their birth, intensified by the sense of ‘coming home’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julie Mongta-Saunders, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Going forward
results.creator_credit: Laura Bell, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laura Bell reflects on her life through the things that have made her proud. Bell’s family, her community and her achievements are what keep her driven and passionate about her work.

results.title: Totora
results.creator_credit: Martin Cohen, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Performances of two ancient ceremonies from southern Malaita in the Solomon Islands. Totora is a ceremony in which people can behave in ways not normally allowed. Siwa is a ceremony of revenge for a man’s death.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Cohen, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.description: Performances of two ancient ceremonies from southern Malaita in the Solomon Islands. Totora is a ceremony in which people can behave in ways not normally allowed. Siwa is a ceremony of revenge for a man’s death.

results.title: Totems
results.creator_credit: Laura Boulton and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: To the Indian the totem pole is the symbol of life, portraying the relationship between man and beast. Fitting into the landscape of British Columbia, these monuments, witnesses to an ancient and powerful culture, look down at us.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laura Boulton and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Totally f***ed up (D)
results.creator_credit: Gregg Araki, Andrea Sperling and Desperate Pictures
results.brief_description: Independent queer film maker Gregg Araki pays homage to Jean-Luc Godard’s Masculin Feminin with his “15 random celluloid fragments”, Totally fed up. The first in Araki’s teen apocalypse trilogy (“The Doom generation” and “Nowhere” complete the series), the film opens on an article regarding the alarmingly high suicide rate amongst gay teens. Using mainly direct to video camera addresses, “Totally fed up” chronicles the ups and downs (mostly down) of a group of gay teenagers, living in contemporary Los Angeles (presented here as a barren wasteland), as they come to terms with relationships, their sexuality and the sense of hoplessness that envelops them all. Littered with numerous popular culture references, “Totally f***ed up” is divided into various chapter headings like, ‘Lifestyles of the bored and disenfranchised’, giving the film’s sense of impending doom and utter nihilism a shot of much needed irony and humour. Araki’s rejection of what is considered mainstream gay is evident throughout the film, from the prevalant alternative music soundtrack to the lead characters line on homosexuality, “Everything that homos are supposed to like-disco music, drag shows, Joan Crawford- I hate.” Cast includes James Duval, Roko Belic, Susan Beshid, Jenee Gill, Gilbert Luna and Lance May.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregg Araki, Andrea Sperling and Desperate Pictures
